Award.AwardTitle: Bottom-Up Meets Top-Down - An Integrated Undergraduate Nanotechnology Laboratory at NC State

Division.LongName: Div Of Engineering Education and Centers

Award.AbstractNarration:
The goal of this Nanotechnology Undergraduate Education (NUE) in Engineering program at North Carolina State University (NCSU) entitled "NUE: Bottom-Up Meets Top-Down-An Integrated Undergraduate Nanotechnology Laboratory at NC State", under the direction of Dr. Yong Zhu, is to develop an undergraduate Nanotechnology laboratory course, consisting of 10 portable lab modules, in the College of Engineering at NCSU that will provide undergraduate students with hands-on experience in nanotechnology. The theme of this project is the integration of nanotechnology with microsystem technology, i.e., bottom-up synthesis meeting top-down fabrication. It will bridge the "pillars" of nanotechnology-nanomaterials, nanofabrication, nanoscale characterization and nanodevices.

Over 500 undergraduate students at NCSU are expected to be affected by the new lab course and the integration of lab modules to existing nanotechnology courses. Overall this NUE project will encourage more U.S. students to pursue graduate study related to nanotechnology and to train a workforce for the emerging nanotechnology industry. Results of this project will be disseminated to local, regional, and national education communities, both during and after the project. Of note is that regionally the results and educational modules will be shared with K-12 educators at the NC Science Teachers Association and through NCSU's NanoDays.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This grant (Bottom-Up Meets Top-Down - An Integrated Undergraduate Nanotechnology Laboratory at NC State) has resulted in the development of the first nanotechnology laboratory course at the College of Engineering at North Carolina State University, “Introduction to Multidisciplinary Nanotechnology Laboratory.”  Specifically, seven laboratory modules were developed that introduce students to the major areas of nanotechnology - nanomaterials, nanofabrication, nanoscale characterization and nanodevices.  Students  from a variety of departments (Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering, Materials Science and Engineering, Electric and Computer Engineering, Nuclear Engineering and Textile Engineering) completed the nanotechnology laboratory course over the last two years. Evaluation of the project showed that students developed an understanding of the essential knowledge about nanoscience and nanotechnology, the major research tools and techniques to perform nanoscale experiments, and how to communicate nanotechnology to a broad audience. In addition, Co-PIs Jones and Tracy worked with Kenan Fellow Elizabeth Woolard to develop new nanoscale science instructional materials for use with precollege students.

 

The PIs have presented the findings in journal publications and conferences. For example, the team published a paper in the Journal of Nano Education, summarizing the key features of the new course and pedagogical approaches used. The project investigators presented workshops for teachers at the NC Science Teachers Association annual meeting and provided professional development on nanoscale science and engineering for teachers and administrators at the NC Science Leadership Association conference. The primary investigator Yong Zhu presented an invited conference talk at the ASME 2011 International Mechanical Engineering Congress & Exposition in Denver, Colorado. In addition, students presented their final projects to high school students.
